abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is satisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is likely, the institutional
            development impact is modest, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory. Among the several lessons
            learned from this project are the following: 1. The
            political will of government officials to put the objective
            of serving the public above all else is the most important
            fundamental element affecting the willingness to innovate
            and to carry out innovation.   2. Creating an enabling
            environment and a degree of freedom conducive for empowering
            local institutions and officials is more effective than the
            provision of mere technical skills and the introduction of
            new innovative approaches. 3. Part of the conducive
            environment needed for successful innovations are flexible
            procedures. 4. The personal commitment of political leaders
            and the personal integrity of the managers concerned with an
            innovation effort are crucial for its success. 5. Even
            though central government had grown accustomed to a
            top-down, more instructive management style, there was a
            readiness to change to a more facilitating work style. 6.
            Competition, transparency and recognition turned out to be
            effective vehicles to promote local government willingness
            to innovate; an added supporting factor was the central
            government grants which reduced the financial risk. 7. There
            is a need to enhance the capacity of central government to
            better manage Bank-supported projects. 8. Adequate
            consultation with the ultimate subproject beneficiaries is
            one of the most important keys for a subproject's
            success and sustainability.. 9. Projects focusing on
            changing mindsets must focus on enhancing capacities and
            commitment for innovations during preparation. 10. The sense
            of entrepreneurship among local government is still weak.
            11. Institutional adjustments are not feasible without a
            willingness to take certain risks and accept additional
            costs, at least initially. 12. innovations are more likely
            to be successfully implementable where they are not in
            conflict with vested interests of segments of the
            bureaucracy and do not touch fields where the collection of
            fees is a key issue. 13. The success of subprojects depends
            not only on the personal qualities (like competence and
            commitment) of the main actors but also on their position
            within the responsible agencies and on an environment that
            is conducive for innovation and change. 14. Revolving funds
            cannot work if the groups who receive the funds first are
            inconsiderate of the needs of the other groups who need
            funding assistance, if repayment terms are not entirely
            clear, and if the fund managers do not enjoy the full trust
            of the beneficiaries. 15. Direct communication among local
            governments, involving real-life examples and experience
            shared among them, promote innovations. 16. The improvement
            of documentation and the dissemination of the lessons
            learned from the project promote a culture of innovation and
            replication. 17. The will to innovate is stimulated, and
            innovations are more likely to be successful, if central and
            local governments share a political commitment to creating
            an enabling environment and effecting the necessary changes
            of regulations and arrangements.
